bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Hal R. Keeling, January 19, 1948

div1.p: Hench questions Keeling about the transcript of Reed's Indianapolis lecture, in 1900, that Keeling has found. Hench wants to know if the one Keeling found includes more information than Hench's copy, or if it may be Reed's actual manuscript copy.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Hal R. Keeling, January 19, 1948

opener.del:
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Dr. Charles H. Slocumb
opener.add:
Hal R Keeling
5519 N Meridean St, Indianapolis, Ind

div1.p:
I got a great kick out of your letter written yesterday. I'm so far
behind in my correspondence that I dictated 7 hours today to my secretary and
to get you a quick reply I'm writing this at home. First of all let me say
that Mary and I regretted muchly not to have been able to show you a better
brand of hospitality. But unfortunately we were unusually busy the whole time
you were here. This past 10 days we've had two house guests, 3 additional vis-
iting friends at the Kahler and 3 visiting doctors especially invited five weeks
ago to come at this time! All this in addition to my routine work. We enjoy
our visitors very much, but at times things get a bit complicated.

After getting one of our house guests into the hospital for surgery,
Mary and I tried to locate you and were sorry to hear you had left.

Now, I can't tell you how thrilled I am to hear of your successes in
finding an old “horse & buggy photo” of the German House. That's swell! I've
wanted that a long time. I'm also most anxious to know what other material
may be available.

Since you were here I borrowed from the University of Minnesota Medi-
cal School the Proceedings of the Indianapolis meeting (1900) to check several
points. (We don't have that issue in the Clinic library.) In these Proceedings
they published Reed's talk, but I can find no discussion whatever of his paper.
Of course (as I've told you) Reed had finished his paper in Cuba so hastily that
he hadn't gotten on the program and had to be introduced as an extra speaker by
Dr. Henry B. Horlbeck of Charleston, South Carolina who introduced Reed thus
(p. 253 of the Proceedings). “Dr. Walter Reed, of the United States Army, has
a paper on “The Etiology of Yellow Fever” which may be of interest to the asso-
ciation, and I move that he be permitted to read it at this time.”

You note that Horlbeck wasn't sure of its value and cautiously said
“--- which may be of interest.” He was taking no chances. The official record
doesn't tell who seconded Horlbeck's motion. The newspapers said Reed spoke
overtime, and at the end of 20 minutes the floor voted to let him continue!
The official Proceedings makes no mention of that.

Even tho' Reed's paper was not expected by the audience and nobody
present had probably had any personal experience with the mosquito theory Reed
was expounding, even so I cannot believe there was NO discussion whatever!!
The newspapers and the Proceedings mention none.

Does the transcript which you located give any dope on these
points:
(1) Who seconded the motion allowing Reed to talk?
(2) Was Reed actually stopped during his paper while
a vote was taken to permit him to continue? If
so, who said what?
(3) Was there any discussion of Reed's paper given
in your “complete transcription”? That would in-
deed be a find, not heretofore ever reported!
(4) Is your “complete transcription” the work of some
hired medical reporter at the meeting, or is it
Reed's actual manuscript!!!

I'm proud to have a reprint (rare and valuable) of this first
paper of Reed's. I enclose it and if your secretary has time to compare
it with the transcription that would be swell! If you find that the trans-
cription is identical with mine, I won't need a copy. But if there is any
deviation, or if your transcription includes discussion, I'm extremely an-
xious to get a copy. And if it is Reed's actual manuscript which he brought
and left with the association's secretary, I must have a photograph at least
of page 1, and indeed I may want photostats of the whole thing.

I'd be delighted to pay whatever the cost is, but I don't want a
photograph merely of some reporter's comments unless there are unreported
data therein. It's a pity I can't borrow the item! Sometimes medical li-
braries which won't lend items to individuals will lend them to other libra-
ries. If so, I could have the librarian of the Mayo Clinic put in a formal
request for this manuscript on inter-library loan.
